thread.title: Rolls-Royce wins two new contracts worth $2.2bn
thread.title_full: Rolls-Royce wins two new contracts worth $2.2bn

author: Sophie Jamieson
title: Rolls-Royce wins two new contracts worth $2.2bn
text:
Comments 
Rolls-Royce has secured two new aerospace contracts worth $2.23bn following a difficult 18 months that has seen the FTSE 100 engineer issue a series of profit warnings . 
The company announced it had been selected by Saudia, the national carrier of Saudi Arabia, to provide an engine service support contract worth $1.3bn. The contract applies to 20 Airbus A330 aircraft with the Trent 700 engine. 
Derby-based Rolls-Royce said the Trent 700 was the “clear market leader” on the A330, making up more than 60pc of new orders over the last three years and now accounting for 90pc of A330 freighters in service and on order. 
Saleh bin Nasser Al-Jasser, director general of Saudi Arabian Airlines, said: "We are pleased to be once again operating the Trent 700 for our latest aircraft. It offers excellent performance and reliability." 
A separate contract, also announced on Monday, saw Rolls chosen by aircraft leasing company International AirFinance Corporation to provide $930m worth of Trent700 engines for 20 A330 planes. 
Eric Schulz, Rolls-Royce, president - Civil Large Engines, said: "We welcome our customer's continued confidence in the Trent 700 as the best solution for fuel burn, emissions and noise performance as well as delivering unrivalled reliability for Middle East operations." 
New Rolls-Royce chief executive Warren East has faced tough challenges at the blue-chip engineering company since he started the job two weeks ago. 
In his first week he told investors the company was downgrading profit guidance, driving share values down.
